dc:description:
NHEJ1 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Cernunnos-XLF deficiency in 2003 (Dai et al., PMID: 12604777). Cernunnos-XLF deficiency is a severe combined immunodeficiency (NHEJ1-SCID) characterized by profound T- and B-lymphocytopenia, microcephaly, growth retardation, and sensitivity to ionizing radiation. At least 9 unique variants (missense, nonsense, frameshift, small insertions, and gross deletions) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental data.

Summary of Case Level Data: 12.70 points.

Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 13 probands in 6 publications (PMID: 16439204, PMID:12604777, PMID: 24511403, PMID: 20597108, PMID: 30666249, PMID: 28741180). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. 

Summary of Experimental Evidence: 4.50 points.

This gene-disease association is supported by animal models, rescue in patient cells, and protein interaction studies (PMID: 17360556, PMID: 16439205, PMID: 16439204). Using yeast two-hybrid screening and coimmunoprecipitation techniques, Ahnesorg P, et al. (2006), demonstrated that XLF directly interacts with the XRCC4-Ligase IV complex in vitro and in vivo and that siRNA-mediated downregulation of XLF in human cell lines leads to radiosensitivity and impaired NHEJ. Zha S, et al. (2007) used gene-targeted mutation to delete exons 4 and 5 from both copies of the Cernunnos-XLF gene in mouse ES cells. Analyses of these ES cells showed they produce no readily detectable Cernunnos-XLF protein, are highly sensitive to ionizing radiation, and have intrinsic DNA DSB repair defects. Additionally, the Cernunnos-XLF mutations led to increased spontaneous genomic instability, including translocations.

In summary, there is definitive evidence to support the relationship between NHEJ1 and autosomal recessive Cernunnos-XLF deficiency. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. 

This classification was approved by the ClinGen SCID-CID GCEP on the meeting date May 20, 2021 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: Authors conclude that, in mice, Cernunnos-XLF is essential for normal NHEJ-mediated repair of DNA DSBs and that Cernunnos-XLF acts as a genomic caretaker to prevent genomic instability.

Cernunnos-XLF Mutant (CerΔ/Δ) ES Cells were sensitive to ionizing radiation and have DSB repair defects. Cer+/Δ ES cells did not have any significant increase of IR sensitivity when compared with WT ES cells, indicating no substantial haploinsufficient phenotype and also suggesting that the CerΔ allele does not generate a dominant-negative phenotype. Introduction of full-length Cernunnos-XLF protein expressed from a vector stably transfected into CerΔ/Δ ES cells restored the IR sensitivity back to WT levels, demonstrating Cernunnos-XLF deficiency is specifically responsible for the increased IR sensitivity of CerΔ/Δ ES cells. Additionally, three independent Cernunnos-XLF mutant ES cells lines (two CerΔ/Δ and one CerN/N) were analyzed, and all exhibited increased levels of chromosomal abnormalities relative to WT ES cells, including chromosomal breaks and translocations.
evidence.rdfs:label: XLF-deficient murine ES cells

The survival curves of these transduced cells after ionizing radiation (0, 1, and 3Gy) indicated a return to an overall normal radiosensitivity as compared to control cells (Figure  5A). Likewise,  the V(D)J recombination was fully restored upon transfection of wt Cernunnos, as demonstrated by the complete ApalI digestion of  PCR-amplified signal joins (Figure  5B)  and in-chromosome V(D)J assay (Figure S4). evidence.dc:description: Authors conclude that the DSB repair defect of 2BN cells is a consequence of impaired XLF function.

Authors observed that non-complemented 2BN cells had high background levels of γH2AX foci even in the absence of irradiation, suggesting that they are unable to effectively repair spontaneously arising DSBs. By contrast, XLF complemented 2BN-C237 cells exhibited foci levels that were equivalent to those of NHEJ-proficient MRC5 cells. Rates of DSB repair as assessed by the disappearance of γH2AX foci took place as effectively in 2BN-C237 cells as in NHEJ-proficient MRC5 cells. By contrast, 2BN cells displayed high levels of IR-induced γH2AX foci, and no reduction was observed in the first 6 hr of the time course studied after irradiation. NHEJ defect of 2BN cells is indeed corrected by XLF expression. Authors established by analysis of DSB repair by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis that 2BN cells display a defect in repairing IR-induced DSBs and that this defect is corrected in XLF-complemented 2BN-C237 cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: XLF-Complemented 2BN Cells Are Proficient in DNA DSB Repair

evidence.dc:description: Using yeast two-hybrid screening and coimmunoprecipitation authors demonstrate that XLF directly interacts with the XRCC4-Ligase IV complex in vitro and in vivo and that siRNA-mediated downregulation of XLF in human cell lines leads to radiosensitivity and impaired NHEJ.

"XRCC4 contains a globular N-terminal “head” domain—which might interact with other proteins and/or DNA—and a protruding helical coiled-coil region that contains a motif that interacts directly with the linker region between the two BRCT domains of Ligase IV. XRCC4 is tightly associated with Ligase IV in vivo and is required for its stability. Furthermore, it has been shown that XRCC4 stimulates Ligase IV adenylation and overall activity in vitro and in vivo. Subsequently, it was shown that targeted inactivation of the genes for Ligase IV or XRCC4 in mouse cells leads to radiosensitivity and NHEJ defects and that human patients with inherited hypomorphic mutations in Ligase IV are radiosensitive and also display varying degrees of immune deficiency."
evidence.rdfs:label: Screen for XRCC4 Interactors

evidence.dc:description: NM_024782.2(NHEJ1):c.11dup (p.Glu5fs), Ahnesorg et al. 2006 (PMID: 16439205) identified an insertion of thymine at nucleotide 12 of the first coding exon of the NHEJ1 gene in the 2BN cell line derived from patient 2BN. The mutation resulted in a frameshift and a truncated 46-amino acid protein. Ahnesorg et al. (2006) could not rule out the possibility that the mutation did not totally inactivate NHEJ1 activity and that some NHEJ1 protein with residual function was made from alternative downstream translational initiation codons, however, authors did show lack of mRNA/protein expression in patient 2BN cells (Fig. 4B and 4C) and performed a rescue experiment to demonstrate that re-introduction of WT XLF into patient-derived cells corrects radiosensitivity and NHEJ defects.

evidence.rdfs:label: 2BN
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequence Analysis. "Inheritance consistent with a recessive mutation"
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: SCID and sensitivity to ionizing radiation but without microcephaly and only mild developmental delay. Small stature. NK cell predominant form of combined immunodeficiency.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Immunologic evaluation of patient 2BN at 1 yr of age found low IgG (103 mg/dl; normal: 363–971 mg/dl), IgA (<7 mg/dl; normal: 27–169 mg/dl) and borderline low IgM titers (30 mg/dl; normal 28–113 mg/dl). The patient had low T and B lymphocyte counts with greatly increased NK cell counts. NK cell function was normal, whereas T lymphocyte proliferation responses to mitogens were at background levels. Cells derived from this patient show dramatic radiosensitivity, decreased double-strand break rejoining, and reduced fidelity in signal and coding joint formation during V(D)J recombination.

evidence.dc:description: NM_024782.2(NHEJ1):c.390+1G>C Splice Donor. RNA extracted from healthy control blood showed a single-band corresponding to the expected mRNA sequence of exon 2-3-4, which was confirmed by Sanger sequencing. The patients exhibited two discrete bands, both of which smaller than wildtype product. The upper band was the result of a skipping of 69 bp at the 3′ end of exon 3, Δ 69 bp. The lower band, Δ Ex3, was due to exon 2 being followed by exon 4 with complete splicing out of exon 3. Both of these changes are in-frame deletions. Immunoblotting did not reveal the full-sized NHEJ1 protein in patient PBMCs but surprisingly, there were no smaller truncated NHEJ1 products either corresponding to the expected molecular weights of the Δ 69 bp and Δ Ex3 isoforms.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1 Sheikh 2017
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted NGS: splice site mutation in NHEJ1. Since no other genic or splice site variant survived the filtering algorithm. Sanger sequencing confirmed that all affected children were homozygous for the mutation (NM_024782.2:c.390+1G>C), which lies immediately downstream of exon 3, and that it fully segregated with the disease state in all individual authors had access to.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Developmental delay, microcephaly with dysmorphic features, neurological manifestations, Pancytopenia, recurrent chest infections, bird facies, high-arched palate, radial deviation of little fingers, sloping forehead, large nose, and ears. The patient also has small stature as well as mild micrognathia. CNS exam revealed hyperreflexia, no clonus, and no focal lesion.

evidence.dc:description: NM_024782.3(NHEJ1):c.169C>T (p.Arg57Ter), Nonsense mutation. Authors analyze DSB rejoining in primary fibroblasts from both patients by enumerating the rate of loss of γ-H2AX foci following exposure to γ-IR. The results showed impaired DSB rejoining after treatment with γ-irradiation and etoposide in both patients.

evidence.rdfs:label: Recio Patient 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted NGS sequencing panel for 192 PID-related genes was performed and revealed a homozygous nucleotide substitution in exon 2 of NHEJ1 gene (NM_024782, c.169C>T) that affects codon 57 and is predicted to result in a severely truncated protein (p.R57X). Sanger sequencing confirmed the variants in the patients which were inherited in autosomal recessive fashion from healthy parents.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Milder immunophenotype, growth retardation, facial dysmorphism, autoimmunity, thrombocytopenia, respiratory tract infections
evidence.previousTestingDescription: B-cell profile in P2 showed a normal proportion of naive, unswitched memory, switched memory, transitional, and plasmoblast B-cells.

evidence.dc:description: NM_024782.2(NHEJ1):c.169C>G(p.Arg57Gly) and NM_024782.2(NHEJ1):c.367T>C(p.Cys123Arg), 2 missense variants. Functional Evidence: Complementation of the NHEJ Defect by wt Cernunnos - results confirm that the identified Cernunnos mutations are responsible for the defective DNA repair in this series of patients.

evidence.rdfs:label: P1
evidence.detectionMethod: Sequence analysis. Confirmed the autosomal recessive inheritance of the identified mutations by sequencing parents’ DNA in all cases.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Growth retardation, chromosomal alterations, urogenital and bone malformations, bacterial infections, autoimmune anemia. Died at 18 years of septic shock.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Primary skin fibroblasts from patients P1-P3 exhibited an increased sensitivity to γ ray exposure as compared to control cells in a clonogenic assay. Although the level of IR sensitivity was variable among the patients, it was equivalent/sometimes more pronounced than what was observed in other radiosensitive conditions. DNA-end ligation assay: Defective DNA multimerization when using extracts from P1-P5 strongly argued for a NHEJ defect in these patients. The patients' extracts cross-complemented the L4 extract in this assay - eliminating a DNA Lig4 deficiency in P1-P5.

evidence.dc:description: NM_024782.3(NHEJ1):c.526C>T (p.Arg176Ter) Nonsense mutation. Compound heterozygous. Mother presented with a 6.9-kb deletion, however, further sequencing of the NHEJ1 gene failed to detect the second maternal variant in P4.

evidence.previousTestingDescription: Analyses of the NBN, LIGIV, and RAD50 genes, showed no mutation. Radiosensitivity was assessed by chromosomal breakage test in fibroblasts of P5 in response to 0.5 and 1.0 Gy radiation (Fig. 5). The chromosomal damage following radiation was compared to that of a normal control cell line and a cell line of an NBS patient. The cells of P5 showed a high spontaneous breakage rate (0.38; normal range: 0.00–0.06) and extremely high levels of damage after IR, which were higher than those of an NBS patient.

evidence.dc:description: NM_024782.2(NHEJ1):c.177+1_177+3delinsTT, Splice Donor. Homozygous deletion of G267, the last nucleotide of exon 2 in the NHEJ1 gene, as well as a homozygous A-to-T change 3 nucleotides downstream in intron 2. These associated mutations resulted in a mixed RNA population in which normally spliced RNAs carried the G267 deletion, which led to a frameshift and premature termination, and numerous aberrant splicing events led to severely truncated proteins. Functional Evidence: Complementation of the NHEJ Defect by wt Cernunnos - results confirm that the identified Cernunnos mutations are responsible for the defective DNA repair in this series of patients.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Growth retardation, recurrent perianal abscess, severe growth failure, bird-like face, preaxial polydactyly on right hand, mild combined immunodeficiency
evidence.previousTestingDescription: NBS1 mutation was found to be negative. Laboratory investigations: prominent neutropenia (500–1500/mm3) and low Ig levels (IgG: 140 mg/dL, IgA: 22.6 mg/dL, and IgM: 84 mg/dL). Patient absolute lymphocyte count was normal and the percentage of CD3+ cells was 91% in the peripheral blood. But CD19+ and CD20+ cells were found to be absent.
